channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistani Taliban’s New Leader Planned Attack on Teenage Activist
item.description: In a surprise choice, the militant group appointed Mullah Fazlullah, the commander responsible for last year’s shooting of Malala Yousafzai.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: India Ink: Manmohan Singh’s Sri Lanka Dilemma
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s forthcoming visit to Sri Lanka has triggered a political controversy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JYOTI MALHOTRA
item.media:description: Tamil women in Jaffna, Sri Lanka, on Aug. 27, holding images of their family members, who reportedly went missing during the war between the Sri Lankan army and the separatist group, Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam.

item.title: European Central Bank Cuts Main Rate
item.description: The E.C.B. moved to stimulate the economy with an unexpected reduction of its benchmark interest rate to 0.25 percent, a record low.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, head of the European Central Bank, which cut a key interest rate on Thursday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Struggle for Balanced Surveillance
item.description: The disappearance of a terrorism suspect in Britain has raised concerns over a form of surveillance known as Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Former Leader of Pakistan Is Freed on Bail
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, who faces a range of criminal charges, can now travel freely within the country after six months of house arrest.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Inspectors Verify Another Chemical Site in Syria
item.description: International inspectors had not been able to reach the location in the northern Aleppo region earlier because of fighting in the country’s bloody civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Signals Flexibility as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
item.description: An American official said that a short suspension of the Iranian program would give negotiators time to pursue a comprehensive and far more challenging agreement.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Greek Police Raid Occupied Broadcasting Station
item.description: Employees of ERT, the former state broadcaster, had occupied its headquarters since the government shut it down in June, prompting a political crisis.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: A woman outside the ERT office argued with police officers on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Indian Lawmaker Charged With Information Law Activist’s Murder
item.description: A member of the Indian parliament has been arrested on the charges of conspiring to kill a Right to Information activist in the western state of Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Balu Bhai Socha, a local environmental activist, standing at the end of a swath of land dug out by illegal limestone mining in Gir National Forest, in Gujarat, on Nov. 12, 2010.

item.title: India Ink: Shrinking Numbers and Growing Persecution Threaten Sikhs and Hindus in Afghanistan
item.description: Most Hindus and Sikhs in Afghanistan are anxious about their prospects after American troops withdraw from the country at the end of 2014.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: J. K. Sharma, a Sikh magician at his shop in Shor Bazaar in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Aug. 7.

item.title: Cyprus in Plan to Develop a Natural Gas Industry
item.description: The island nation seeks to rebuild its economy after the collapse of its banking industry, but its natural gas industry so far exists mainly in theory.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: The Cyprus energy minister, Yiorgos Lakkotrypis, is a former Microsoft executive.

item.title: Germany Considers Having Snowden Testify to Inquiry
item.description: As anger over United States surveillance continues, German officials said they would explore having Edward J. Snowden testify to a parliamentary inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,274 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: National Briefing | Military: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Look at Secret Records
item.description: The judge, Col. James Pohl, has ordered the government to show him confidential correspondence about prison conditions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a defense lawyer said Wednesday.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Mannequins Give Shape to a Venezuelan Fantasy
item.description: Mannequins with bulging bosoms have become standard in Venezuela, reflecting the country’s embrace of plastic surgery even among those who can least afford it.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mannequin factory in Valencia, Venezuela, where the voluptuous models are the standard.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands Appeals Detentions of Greenpeace Activists in Russia
item.description: Russia, which has charged Greenpeace crew members with hooliganism, refused to recognize the jurisdiction of an international tribunal in what it considers an internal legal matter.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Court Orders Full Sentence in Drug Agent’s Death, but Killer Is Free
item.description: The Mexico Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a lower court ruling that allowed a drug kingpin accused of murdering an American drug enforcement agent in the 1980s to walk free.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: China Wants Its Movies to Be Big in the U.S., Too
item.description: China’s ambitious new film entrepreneurs, dozens of whom gathered in California this week for industry events, want something that has largely eluded them: a homemade global hit.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: “Man of Tai Chi,” a Chinese-American film, sold few tickets.

item.title: Chinese Leader’s Economic Plan Tests Goal to Fortify Party Power
item.description: President Xi Jinping faces the daunting task of reconciling promises of market-driven economic reform with his goal to reinforce the Communist Party’s pillars of control.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A worker walked past a palace used by ancient emperors in Shenyang, China. President Xi Jinping wants to promote market competition while simultaneously reinforcing the Communist Party’s power.

item.title: In Fractured Nepal, Plans for National Elections Provide a Series of Subplots
item.description: After decades of political upheaval, there is a growing consensus that the only way to arrest Nepal’s economic spiral is through elections, including one to finish the constitution.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: The European Central Bank’s Inflation Conundrum
item.description: Ahead of the bank’s meeting on Thursday, debate is heating up over whether a sharp drop in inflation is a sign of health — or impending stagnation.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank. He has given little public indication of whether the bank will make a move on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Will Ease Sanctions if Iran Halts Nuclear Program, Official Says
item.description: An Obama administration official said that an Iranian agreement to halt nuclear activity, for six months perhaps, would buy time for negotiators to work out a more sweeping deal.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: An Iranian technician in the uranium conversion facility outside the city of Isfahan, in 2007.

item.title: Antakya Journal: Next Door to War, There’s Money to Be Made
item.description: A half-dozen military supply stores are a source of military vests, camouflage pants, knives and gas masks for a clientele flooding in from all over the Middle East.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mannequin in camouflage advertises the merchandise at a military supply shop in Antakya.

item.title: Russians Meet With an Uncle of Assad in an Effort to Jump-Start Peace Talks
item.description: Rifaat al-Assad, an uncle of President Bashar al-Assad, was forced out of the country in 1984 after attempting to lead a coup.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Syrian State News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A man carried an injured child after an explosion in front of the train station in central Damascus.

item.title: Ruble Hopes to Join Ranks of the $ and €
item.description: Russian officials want to give the ruble a symbol that would become as easily recognizable as those for the dollar and the euro.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
